docs.title: Welcome to Biology Problems
docs.text: Explore free and open problem sets for Biochemistry, Genetics, and more! Click on a subject to get started.

docs.title: Subjects
docs.text:
• Biochemistry
  • Genetics

docs.title: List of Biochemistry Topics
docs.text: Explore the foundational concepts and techniques in Biochemistry. Click on a topic to dive deeper.

docs.title: Topics
docs.text:
1. The Molecular Design of Life

    • Molecular design of life, major elements, and biomacromolecules.

  2. Water Chemistry and pH

    • Properties of water, pH, pKa, and buffering systems.

  3. Amino Acids

    • Amino acid structure, types, and roles in protein structure.

  4. Proteins: Structure and Folding

    • Protein folding, structural levels, and mechanisms.

  5. Protein Purification Techniques

    • Isolation and analysis methods, chromatography, electrophoresis.

  6. Enzymes Reactions and Thermodynamics

    • Enzyme functions, substrate binding, and energy changes in reactions.

  7. Enzyme Kinetics and Inhibition

    • Reaction rates, enzyme efficiency, and inhibition mechanisms.

  8. Ligand Binding, Allostery, and Regulation

    • Ligand binding, allosteric effects, and feedback regulation.

  9. Carbohydrates: Monosaccharides to Polysaccharides

    • Carbohydrate structure, glycosidic bonds, biological roles.

  10. Nucleic Acids: Structure and Applications

    • Nucleotide structure, DNA/RNA functions, biotechnology applications.

  11. Biochemistry of Human Senses

    • Taste, smell, hearing, sight, and touch.

"Click to show example problem on Types of Chemical Bonds"

Which one of the following types of chemical bonds correspond to the example 'Mg2+ • 2× Cl- (magnesium chloride)'.

  • A. hydrogen bond
  • B. ionic bond
  • C. non-polar covalent bond
  • D. polar covalent bond
Check Answer

  • B. Methyl

docs.title: Types of Macromolecules
docs.text:
Download the bbq-MC-macromolecules-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Types of Macromolecules"

Which one of the following types of macromolecules correspond to the macromolecule 'lactalbumin – whey polypeptides found in milk'.

  • A. carbohydrates
  • B. lipids
  • C. nucleic acids
  • D. proteins
Check Answer

docs.title: Hydrophobic Compounds from Molecular Formulas
docs.text:
Download the bbq-which_hydrophobic-simple-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Hydrophobic Compounds from Molecular Formulas" Based on their molecular formula, which one of the following compounds is most likely hydrophobic?
  • A. ethanol, CH3CH2OH 
  • B. butane, CH3CH2CH2CH3
  • C. erythrose, C4H8O4
  • D. methanol, CH3OH 
  • E. glycine, NH2CH2COOH 
Check Answer

docs.title: Macromolecule Types Based on Chemical Structures
docs.text:
Download the bbq-which_macromolecule-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Macromolecule Types Based on Chemical Structures" Guide to Identifying the Chemical Structures of Macromolecules Carbohydrates (monosaccharides)
  • Should have about the same number of oxygens as carbons.
  • Look for hydroxyl groups (–OH) attached to the carbon atoms.
  • Carbonyl groups (C=O) are often present as well.
  • Look for the base unit of CH2O.
  • Larger carbohydrates will form hexagon or pentagon ring-like structures.
Lipids (fatty acids)
  • Contain mostly carbon and hydrogen.
  • Very few oxygens and often no nitrogens.
  • Fats and oils will have carboxyl groups (–COOH) and ester bonds
  • Look for long chains or ring structures of only carbon and hydrogen.
  • Steroids have four interconnected carbon rings.
Proteins (amino acids and dipeptides)
  • Always have a nitrogen/amino group (–NH2 or –NH3+)
  • Always have a carboxyl group (–COOH or –COO-)
  • Identify the central Cα (alpha-carbon) attached to an amino group and a carboxyl group
  • Larger protein macromolecules will have a characteristic peptide bond (C–N)
  • Try to identify common side chains (R groups).
Nucleic acids (nucleobases)
  • Must have a nucleobase, rings containing carbon and nitrogen.
  • Larger nucleic acids will have a sugar backbone and phosphate groups.
Phosphate groups (–PO42-)
  • Found in all of the macromolecule types.
  • It is best to ignore them to not let them confuse you.
  • The breakdown of carbohydrates involves add phosphates.
  • Membrane lipids have phosphate head groups.
  • Many proteins are phosphorylated for regulatory purposes.
  • DNA has a phosphate backbone.

Molecule Information Full name Arachidic acid Molecular formula C20 H40 O2 Molecular weight 312.50 g/mol Image link link to static image Partition coefficient 8.5 logP C/(O+N) ratio 10.0 Which one of the four main types of macromolecules is represented by the chemical structure of arachidic acid shown above?
  • A. Carbohydrates (monosaccharides)
  • B. Lipids (fatty acids)
  • C. Proteins (amino acids and dipeptides)
  • D. Nucleic acids (nucleobases)
Check Answer

docs.title: Topic 2: Water Chemistry and pH
docs.text: Properties of water, pH, pKa, and buffering systems.

docs.title: Correct Form of the Henderson-Hasselbalch Equation
docs.text:
Download the bbq-Henderson-Hasselbalch-EQUATION-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Correct Form of the Henderson-Hasselbalch Equation"

Which one of the following equations is the correct form of the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation?

  • A.

    pH = pKa – log10[A–][HA]

  • B.

    pH = pKa + log10[A–][HA]

Check Answer

docs.title: Optimal Buffering Range using pKa
docs.text:
Download the bbq-optimal_buffering_range-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Optimal Buffering Range using pKa"

Pyrophosphoric acid and its conjugate base, pyrophosphate, is abbreviated PPi and is formed by cells from the hydrolysis of ATP into AMP.Pyrophosphoric acid is tetraprotic with pKa values of 0.91, 2.10, 6.70, and 9.32.Which one of the following pH values falls outside the optimal buffering rangeof Pyrophosphoric acid?

  • A. pH 0.5
  • B. pH 1.8
  • C. pH 5.0
  • D. pH 5.9
  • E. pH 10.1
Check Answer

docs.title: Most Abundant Diprotic State at pH using pKa
docs.text:
Download the bbq-pKa_buffer_state-2_protons-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Most Abundant Diprotic State at pH using pKa"

Malic acid and its conjugate base, malate, is the main acid in many fruits and is an intermediate in the citric acid cycle.Malic acid is diprotic with pKa values of 3.40 and 5.20.Malic acid has three possible protonation states in the choices below.Which one of the following protonation states is the most abundant at pH 6.0?

  • A. (COO)CH2CH(OH)COO2-
  • B. (COOH)CH2CH(OH)COO-
  • C. (COOH)CH2CH(OH)COOH
Check Answer

docs.title: Most Abundant Triprotic State at pH using pKa
docs.text:
Download the bbq-pKa_buffer_state-3_protons-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Most Abundant Triprotic State at pH using pKa"

Citric acid and its conjugate base, citrate, is an intermediate in the citric acid cycle.Citric acid is triprotic with pKa values of 3.13, 4.76, and 6.39.Citric acid has four possible protonation states in the choices below.Which one of the following protonation states is the most abundant at pH 5.5?

  • A. HOC3H4(COOH)3
  • B. HOC3H4(COOH)2(COO)-
  • C. HOC3H4(COOH)(COO)22-
  • D. HOC3H4(COO)33-
Check Answer

docs.title: Most Abundant Tetraprotic State at pH using pKa
docs.text:
Download the bbq-pKa_buffer_state-4_protons-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Most Abundant Tetraprotic State at pH using pKa"

Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid and its conjugate base, EDTA, is commonly used in chelation therapy and as a chelating agent in biochemical experiments..Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid is tetraprotic with pKa values of 2.00, 2.67, 6.16, and 10.26.Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid has five possible protonation states in the choices below.Which one of the following protonation states is the most abundant at pH 11.0?

  • A. C10H12N2O84-
  • B. C10H13N2O83-
  • C. C10H14N2O82-
  • D. C10H15N2O8-
  • E. C10H16N2O8
Check Answer

docs.title: Topic 3: Amino Acids
docs.text: Amino acid structure, types, and roles in protein structure.

docs.title: Determining Dipeptide Sequence from Structure
docs.text:
Download the bbq-2_amino_acids-polypeptide_mc_sequence-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Determining Dipeptide Sequence from Structure" peptide_4529

A dipeptide is made up of two (2) amino acids. The figure above shows one such dipeptide with an unknown sequence. Your task is to find out the two (2) letter sequence of this dipeptide.Here is a step-by-step guide to help you answer the question:

  1. Consult an amino acid guide for reference. You can find a PDF guide on Blackboard under "Exam and Quiz" in the "Old Exams" section, with the filename bchm_exam-help_sheet.pdf, or search online for a visual guide that shows all 20 amino acids with their single-letter codes.
  2. Identify the amino-terminal end, represented as NH3+ and highlighted in bright green. Distinguish between the general nitrogens in amino acid backbones (denoted as NH) and the nitrogen in amino acid side chains.
  3. The one (1) peptide bonds connecting the two (2) amino acids are highlighted in bright green, making it easier to distinguish the two (2) amino acids.
  4. Examine the side chain for each of the two (2) amino acids to determine their single-letter amino acid code.
  5. List the single-letter amino acid codes in the amino to carboxyl (N→C) direction. This is the standard method for writing peptide sequences.

Select the correct peptide sequence from the options below:

  • A. QW 
  • B. FW 
  • C. MC 
  • D. QC 
  • E. YH 
Check Answer

"Click to show example problem on Levels of Protein Structure"

Which one of the following levels of protein structure correspond to the description 'backbone hydrogen bonding in α-helices'.

  • B. quaternary
  • C. secondary
  • D. tertiary
Check Answer

docs.title: Hydrogen Bonding in Alpha-Helix Structures
docs.text:
Download the bbq-alpha_helix_h-bonds-MC-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Hydrogen Bonding in Alpha-Helix Structures"

The α-helix is a right-handed coil in which each backbone N–H group forms a hydrogen bond with the C=O group of an amino acid located a few residues away. The regular pattern of hydrogen bonding stabilizes the helix, preventing it from unraveling.In a long α-helix, amino acid number 7 would form a hydrogen bond with which two other amino acids?Select the correct pair of amino acids below.

  • A. amino acids 5 and 9 (a residue shift of 2 positions) 
  • B. amino acids 4 and 10 (a residue shift of 3 positions) 
  • C. amino acids 3 and 11 (a residue shift of 4 positions) 
  • D. amino acids 2 and 12 (a residue shift of 5 positions) 
  • E. amino acids 1 and 13 (a residue shift of 6 positions) 
Check Answer

docs.title: Ionic Bond Formation in Amino Acid Side Chains

Download the bbq-ionic_bond_amino_acids-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Ionic Bond Formation in Amino Acid Side Chains" Based on the chemical properties of amino acid side chains, which pair of amino acids listed below can form an ionic bond between their side chains?
  • A. Threonine and Serine 
  • B. Tyrosine and Glutamate 
  • C. Cysteine and Histidine 
  • D. Tyrosine and Serine 
  • E. Glutamic Acid and Histidine 
Check Answer

docs.title: Determining Net Charge of Proteins at Given pH
docs.text:
Download the bbq-isoelectric_one_protein-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Determining Net Charge of Proteins at Given pH" Isoelectric Point Problem Protein Name isoelectric point (pI) molecular weight Casein (Cas) 4.9 24.0

The protein in the table (above) is placed in a buffer solution with a pH of 3.5.What is the correct net charge on the Cas protein at pH of 3.5?

  • A. The protein will have a net positive (+) charge. 
  • B. The protein will have a net negative (–) charge. 
  • C. The protein will have a net neutral (0) charge. 
Check Answer

docs.title: Protein Migration Direction Based on Isoelectric Point
docs.text:
Download the bbq-isoelectric_two_proteins-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Protein Migration Direction Based on Isoelectric Point" Isoelectric Point Problem

A mixture of two proteins are to be separated by isoelectric focusing.

ProteinName IsoelectricPoint (pI) MolecularWeight Myoglobin (Myo) 7.0 18.0 Ovalbumin (Ova) 4.6 45.0

Both protein samples are placed into a gel with a constant pH of 3.5. The gel is then placed into an electric field.In which direction will each protein in the table migrate at pH 3.5?

  • A. Both Myo and Ova will have a negative (–) charge and travel towards the positive (+) terminal 
  • B. Both Myo and Ova will have a positive (+) charge and travel towards the negative (–) terminal 
  • C. Myo will have a positive (+) charge and travel towards the negative (–) terminal Ova will have a negative (–) charge and travel towards the positive (+) terminal 
  • D. Myo will have a negative (–) charge and travel towards the positive (+) terminal Ova will have a positive (+) charge and travel towards the negative (–) terminal 
Check Answer

docs.title: Estimating Protein Molecular Weight from SDS-PAGE Migration
docs.text:
Download the bbq-protein_gel_migration-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Estimating Protein Molecular Weight from SDS-PAGE Migration" Gel Migration Problem

In this task, data from an SDS-PAGE experiment, where proteins are separated based on molecular weight, is provided. The gel results table below shows some standard proteins with known molecular weights and one unknown protein.

Protein Name MolecularWeight (kDa) MigrationDistance (cm) Cytochrome c (Cyt) 13.0 3.45 Avidin (Av) 16.9 3.24 Agglutinin (Agg) 22.0 3.03 Prostate-Specific Antigen (PSA) 30.0 2.78 Epidermal Growth Factor (EGF) 40.0 2.55 Luciferase (Luc) 50.0 2.37 Serum Albumin (Alb) 66.2 2.15 Unknown ? 2.88 Estimate the molecular weight of the unknown protein by comparing its gel migration distance with those of the standards.
  • A. 16 kDa 
  • B. 20 kDa 
  • C. 27 kDa 
  • D. 36 kDa 
  • E. 43 kDa 
Check Answer

docs.title: Topic 6: Enzymes Reactions and Thermodynamics
docs.text: Enzyme functions, substrate binding, and energy changes in reactions.

docs.title: Energy Terms and Their Categories
docs.text:
Download the bbq-MC-energy_terms-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Energy Terms and Their Categories"

Which one of the following energy requirement categories correspond to the energy term 'formation of polymers'.

  • A. releases energy
  • B. requires energy input
Check Answer

docs.title: True/False Statements on Chemical Reactions
docs.text:
Download the bbq-TF-chemical_reactions-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on True/False Statements on Chemical Reactions"

Which one of the following statements is FALSE regarding chemical reactions?

  • A. Chemical reactions always involve the forming and breaking of chemical bonds 
  • B. For chemical reactions to happen, the chemical identity of both reactants and products remains the same. 
  • C. The rate of a chemical reactions depend on temperature, pressure, and the presence of catalysts. 
  • D. Chemical reactions are always either exothermic or endothermic. 
  • E. Chemical reactions always transform one or more substances into one or more different substances. 
Check Answer

docs.title: True/False Statements on Gibbs Free Energy (ΔG = ΔH - T ΔS)
docs.text:
Download the bbq-TF-gibbs_free_energy_equation-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on True/False Statements on Gibbs Free Energy (ΔG = ΔH - T ΔS)"

Which one of the following statements is TRUE of the Gibbs free energy, ΔG = ΔH – TΔS?

  • A. entropy is associated with the amount of heat exchanged with the environment 
  • B. Tis the temperature in degrees Fahrenheit
  • C. ΔS is the change in entropy
  • D. When ΔH = 0 the reaction has reached equilibrium 
  • E. When ΔH < 0 the reaction is calledspontaneous
Check Answer

docs.title: True/False Statements on Thermodynamics vs. Kinetics
docs.text:
Download the bbq-TF-thermodynamics-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on True/False Statements on Thermodynamics vs. Kinetics"

Which one of the following statements is FALSE concerning thermodynamics and kinetics?

  • A. Kinetics describes the rate at which a reaction approaches equilibrium. 
  • B. In general, an increase in disorder or randomness corresponds to an increase in entropy. 
  • C. Enzymes must be regenerated after each reaction they catalyze. 
  • D. The change in Gibbs free energy (ΔG) of a reaction is related to the enthalpy and entropy changes of the reaction. 
  • E. Enzymes do NOT change the overall change in free energy (ΔG) of a reaction. 
Check Answer

docs.title: Topic 7: Enzyme Kinetics and Inhibition
docs.text: Reaction rates, enzyme efficiency, and inhibition mechanisms.

docs.title: Enzyme Inhibition and Activation in Metabolic Pathways
docs.text:
Download the bbq-BCHM355-metabolic_pathway_inhibitor-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Enzyme Inhibition and Activation in Metabolic Pathways"

A series of enzymes catalyze the reactions in the following metabolic pathway:

enzyme 1 enzyme 2 enzyme 3 enzyme 4 F  ⟶  G  ⟶  H  ⟶  I  ⟶  J

Understanding the type of enzyme inhibition or activation is crucial for developing effective drugs and understanding metabolic regulation.

enzyme 1 converts substrate F into product G.

The end product J of this pathway binds to enzyme 1and its substrate in the active site at the same time.This binding decreases the activity of the enzyme.Determine the type of enzyme inhibition or activation described:

  • A. catalytic converter 
  • B. enzyme activator 
  • C. non-competitive inhibitor 
  • D. un-competitive inhibitor 
  • E. competitive inhibitor 
Check Answer

docs.title: Enzyme Catalysis Terminology
docs.text:
Download the bbq-MC-enzyme_terminology-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Enzyme Catalysis Terminology"

Which one of the following terms related to enzyme catalysis correspond to the definition 'a complete enzyme complex'.

  • A. Apoenzyme
  • B. Coenzyme
  • C. Holoenzyme
  • D. Reactant
Check Answer

docs.title: True/False Statements on Enzyme Kinetics
docs.text:
Download the bbq-TF-enzyme_equilibrium-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on True/False Statements on Enzyme Kinetics"

Which one of the following statements is TRUE of enzyme kinetics?

  • A. enzymes alter the Gibbs free energy (ΔG) of a chemical reaction 
  • B. enzymes reduce the rate of a chemical reaction 
  • C. enzymes cannot change the equilibrium of the chemical reaction 
  • D. enzymes only convert substrate to product and NOT the reverse 
  • E. enzymes eliminate the activation energy of a chemical reaction. 
Check Answer

docs.title: True/False Statements on Michaelis-Menten Kinetics
docs.text:
Download the bbq-TF-m-m_kinetics-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on True/False Statements on Michaelis-Menten Kinetics"

Which one of the following statements is TRUE of Michaelis-Menten kinetics?

  • A. M-M kinetics assumes that the enzyme-product complex [EP] is constant. 
  • B. The reaction rate is proportional to the product concentration. 
  • C. M-M kinetics assumes that the substrate is NOT available and there is no measureable reverse reaction rate. 
  • D. M-M kinetics does NOT apply to allosteric enzymes. 
  • E. M-M kinetics was developed by Greek economist Leo Michelis and Dutch bobsledder Hubert Menten in 1913. 
Check Answer

docs.title: Which Molecule Cannot be an Enzyme Cofactors
docs.text:
Download the bbq-enzyme_cofactors-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Which Molecule Cannot be an Enzyme Cofactors" Which one of the following molecular entities CANNOT be classified as an enzymatic cofactor?
  • A. quinone, an organic compound involved in electron transport 
  • B. zinc ion, Zn2+
  • C. adenosine triphosphate (ATP) 
  • D. vitamin B12, cobalamins 
  • E. immunoglobulin proteins 
Check Answer

docs.title: Which Molecule Could be an Enzyme
docs.text:
Download the bbq-which_enzyme-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Which Molecule Could be an Enzyme"

Enzymes are biological catalysts that speed up chemical reactions in living organisms.Which one of the following choices is most likely an enzyme?Hint: enzymes often have a distinct naming pattern that can help identify them.

  • A. coenzyme Q 
  • B. testosterone 
  • C. lactate dehydrogenase 
  • D. steroid 
  • E. intermediate filaments 
Check Answer

docs.title: Topic 8: Ligand Binding, Allostery, and Regulation
docs.text: Ligand binding, allosteric effects, and feedback regulation.

docs.title: Allosteric Enzymes in Metabolic Pathways
docs.text:
Download the bbq-metabolic_pathway_allosteric-questions.txt file for Blackboard Upload

"Click to show example problem on Allosteric Enzymes in Metabolic Pathways"

A series of enzymes catalyze the reactions in the following metabolic pathway:

enzyme 1 enzyme 2 enzyme 3 enzyme 4 enzyme 5 Q  ⟶  R  ⟶  S  ⟶  T  ⟶  U  ⟶  V

In a typical metabolic pathway, an allosteric enzyme is sensitive to changes in concentration of specific molecules and can regulate the rate of reactions.Which one of the enzymes in the metabolic pathway above is most likely to be an allosteric enzyme?

  • A. enzyme 1 that catalyzes the reaction from substrate Q to product R
  • B. enzyme 2 that catalyzes the reaction from substrate R to product S
  • C. enzyme 3 that catalyzes the reaction from substrate S to product T
  • D. enzyme 4 that catalyzes the reaction from substrate T to product U
  • E. enzyme 5 that catalyzes the reaction from substrate U to product V
Check Answer
